title: Analog Today
body: Analog is the simplest productivity system that helps you prioritize and focus on your most important tasks. 76mm x 127mm printed on 100# smooth uncoated paper with smooth corners.
alt: Minimalist notepad with a list for today

title: Filippa K Turtleneck
body: The first camel addition to the all black wardrobe - it is one of my favourite winter jumpers. It was -8 in Copenhagen and the perfect excuse to pay a visit to Filippa K to pick up a new jumper as a souvenir. There can never be too many turtlenecks in the winter wardrobe.
alt: A camel coloured wool turtleneck jumper

title: Small Transparent Speaker
body: Made out of tempered glass and aluminium, this speaker comes with Bluetooth 5.0 encased in sleek design. It is 3.3kg and about 268mm x 203 mm x 95mm big.
alt: Transparent rectangular speaker with black accents

title: Ricoh GR IIIx
body: Whenever I travel, I have my Sony Alpha camera with me for the occasional street photo. As much as I love shooting full frame, it is quite a big camera to lug about all day. When I heard about the pocket factor of the Ricoh and use of recipes, it was a no brainer.
alt: A pocketable Ricoh GR IIIx camera in black

title: Mac Studio Display
body: A huge fan of the 27 inch 5K retina screen, I can now zoom in 9000x and draw the ultimate pixel perfect rectangles in Figma.
alt: Large silver retina display monitor from Apple

title: Anya Hindmarch Kit Kat
body: This was a surprise Christmas gift from an inside joke. I would often leave the house without an emergency chocolate bar and end up doing a panic run to the nearest convenience store to get a Kit Kat because my blood sugar levels have dropped. Most of why I love this is because of the backstory, but I am also a huge fan of Anya’s playful designs. And now, I will always have an emergency Kit Kat with me.
notes: A gift originally from Florence, Italy
alt: A kit kat bar made in leather

title: Annie Bing Diana Jacket
body: Back when I moved back to Glasgow, I was taking a stroll around the store with no intentions of shopping when I noticed this jacket on a hanger. I loved the menswear inspired fit with the double breasting closing and wool fabric. That was also when I realised I was ready to replace my bomber and denim jackets with more classic pieces.
alt: Black double faced wool jacket from COS

title: Aesop Rozu
body: Floral, green and woody. Described as a fragrance of tender intensity, this is one of my favourite perfumes. The packaging feels expensive, but more importantly, it is not a floral perfume despite the rose. I love the subtle notes of earth, rose and spice that creates a unique scent that I cannot put into words easily.
alt: An amber glass Aesop perfume bottle with a black cap

title: Craighill Ripple (Carbon)
body: Milled from 5/8 inch diameter stainless steel with a Black nitrocarburized finish, it features a classic churchkey-style that is both functional and stylish.
alt: A minimal steel bottle opener with rippled edges

title: Acne Studios Fairview Face
body: Cut from midweight fleece cotton, this classic cut exemplifies the brand’s heritage in simple Scandi style paired with the playful Acne Studios face logo.
alt: Black sweatshirt with classic Acne studio face logo

title: Loewe Anagram Belt
body: I have always loved Loewe and their beautiful anagram logo. Whether it’s jeans of high waisted trousers, I like to style them with a belt and have always wanted one from Loewe. It is simple, the leather and anagram are exquisite, and I love subtle luxury.
alt: Black leather belt with a gold Loewe anagram logo

title: Audo CPH JWDA Lamp
body: Inspired by traditional oil lamps and crafted in glass, solid metal and a brass dimmer switch, the JWDA Portable has the freedom and flexibility to move anywhere you want.
alt: Minimal JWDA dimmable lamp from Audo Copenhagen

title: BoConcept Velvet Leaf
body: Inspired by natural leaves, this decorative sculpture made of curved aluminum is a piece of art that can help give the room a bit of personality.
alt: A black leaf sculpture from BoConcept

title: Ganni City Boot
body: For heeled boots, they are surprisingly comfortable with a well padded chunky heel. Another classic staple in the winter wardrobe, they are my new favourite boots because of how easy they go with everything.
alt: A pair of black heeled rubber boots from Ganni

title: Muuto Base Table
body: Another addition to the plywood furniture family - a beautifully crafted black table top with rounded corners and matte black steel legs, it is both the dining table and daytime work desk.
alt: Black plywood tabletop with matte black steel legs

title: HAY J77
body: I have always been a fan of HAY (and Danish design) so when I needed some new chairs to go with a new Muuto table, I wanted a set of 4 J77 chairs. It is contemporary, minimal, comfortable, and HAY.
alt: A black wooden chair from danish brand, HAY

title: Blue Lucky Cat
body: Three friends and designers walked into Illum one afternoon and three lucky cats were purchased - blue, orange and green. And now, each cat sits somewhere, in each designer’s house as a reminder of the good times. I can also finally say I own one of those Chinese lucky cats.
alt: A blue lucky cat with a waving arm

title: Bao
body: I love food, clean design and physical books. Throw in steamed bun recipes, along with original branding and beautiful layouts, this is one of my favourite books on the bookshelf. Strictly for viewing pleasure, never attempted making a steamed bun.
alt: A blue lucky cat with a waving arm

title: Hay Quilton
body: Crafted by the London design duo Doshi Levein, the sofa is part of the flexible Quilton modular system created with FSC-certified wood from sustainable forests.
alt: Light grey quilted L shaped sofa by HAY

title: Lululemon High Rise Cropped
body: One of my favourite casual bottoms for everday errands, the joggers are cropped at the right length, with a great slim fit that does not make me look like a Hobbit.
alt: Clear Byredo perfume bottle with a black rounded cap

title: Balenciaga City Bag S
body: Ever since 10 years ago, the Balenciaga city bag was one of the first classic bags that I came across and always loved. Just by luck, whilst on a holiday back in Hong Kong, I came by a Balenciaga store that stocked it on the shelves. When I'm not carrying my Rains backpack, this is my other go-to.
notes: Purchased in Hong Kong, Hong Kong
alt: A pocketable Ricoh GR IIIx camera in black

title: Frame Le Original Cropped
body: These jeans are the start of a more relaxed silhouette in my capsule wardrobe. Embracing the freedom of a slim straight cut, my legs feel liberated from the constricting embrace of my old skin tight jeans.
alt: High waisted cropped, straight cut blue jeans

title: Acne Studios Emmbar Face
body: This was one of the first pieces of my capsule wardrobe which was mostly focused on Scandinavian and French brands. Out of all of the black tees, I particularly love this one because of the subtle branding with the Acne Studios face, but also because the cotton is luxurious and soft.
alt: Black Acne Studios short sleeved T-shirt

title: APC Hide
body: White sneakers are a staple of every capsule wardrobe. I wanted a pair that was comfortable and made out of leather. A.P.C are one of my favourite brands for its minimalist, laid-back attitude. My go-to combination is a pair of wide legged trousers, belt and these sneakers.
alt: White APC sneakers in leather

title: Baggu Puffy Sleeve
body: I love this because it's bright, it's fun and it's so puffy. Yes, those are bananas. It is playful yet functional with protecting my laptop as I chuck it about in my bag on the go.
alt: Orange puffy laptop sleeve with a banana print

title: Reformation Mason
body: Wide legged trousers are another staple of a capsule wardrobe but they're not the easiest to find for petites. Not only is the fit perfect from Reformation, but the length was precisely cut right with no alterations needed.
alt: A pair of wide legged high waisted black trousers from Reformation

title: No Idea is Final
body: The living room was all coming together but was missing a pop of colour amongst the black and muted tones. I was checking out a local bookstore when I came across No Idea is Final sitting on a shelf. I loved the orange cover, and loved the layout of the pages even more. And as everyone knows, no idea is ever final with designers.
alt: An orange book from Phaidon publishing

title: Rains Mini Roll Top
body: Given that it rains about 2/3 of the year in Scotland, I initially bought this backpack purely out of functionality. However, it is a great everyday bag that fits my laptop and essentials I need on the go. The sand colour is also a beautiful muted tone.
alt: A sand coloured waterproof roll top backpack

title: Byredo Black Saffron
body: Woody with a hint of spice. This was my first bottle of expensive perfume after discovering Scandinavian design. I went into the store not knowing what I wanted, except something not floral and sweet. After a few sniffs, I ended up with Black Saffron as my favourite choice with Blanche coming in a very close second. Like Aesop, I love how it smells, but also how I am unable to describe it to anyone else because it’s so distinct.
alt: Clear Byredo perfume bottle with a black rounded cap

title: Designing Design
body: Still yet to be read, but I was once told that this was the holy grail of design. I know I should not judge a book by its cover but its crisp and clean design was what initially caught my eye.
alt: A book that talks design and minimalism by Kenya Hara

title: Creative Selection
body: I do not read much books - I just prefer nice picture books. However, this was one of the few books that I finished and is still one of my favourite “product” books to date. Favourite snippet was about how the keyboard on iPhones were made.
alt: A book that talks about Apple's design during the golden age

title: Normann Copenhagen Porta Lamp
body: Dimmable, portable and sleek - that was search criteria for a pair of new bedside lamps. I love the rounded corners, how simple the shape of the lamp is, and no ugly wires in sight.
alt: Black portable and dimmable lamp from Normann Copenhagen

title: Nothing 1
body: When Nothing first launched, I bought the earphones mostly because of its distinct packaging - I love that it is partly transparent so that you can see the inner workings and its sleek branding is consistent throughout the app. Noise cancellation makes a big difference when travelling on flights or working in a busy café - accompanying app is also equally as sleek.
alt: White earphones in a transparent case from Nothing

title: All Saints Rina Tank
body: A basic ribbed tank with a high neckline, it is the perfect bottom layer for the winter, and an easy, comfortable top in the summer. One of the tops also has a hole which came from my French bulldog Zeusz when we met him for the first time as a pup.
alt: A black high neck ribbed tank top

title: Altura Step Stool
body: Designed by Patricia Perez, and named after the Spanish word for height, the Altura stool doubles up as a step stool and quirky bedside table. What I love about how its designed is its versatility as well as the fact that it does not need any assembly.
alt: Black asymmetric step stool that doubles as a side table

title: Stax River Hamburger
body: This was one of the first items that were added to the new home - it was quirky, food related and so well designed with the lettuce doubling up as a funnel holder. Till today, it is still one of my favourite design objects in the home.
alt: A set of wooden coasters that form a hamburger

title: Alessi Plisse
body: New home means new stuff and since it was a home to two designers, we could not have ugly kitchen appliances on the counter. I loved the form and its pleated details with the matt black finishing. Funny enough, a few months later, the Plisse toaster was added to the kitchen.
alt: Matt black Alessi Plisse kettle

title: DOIY Bento
body: This salmon sashimi lunch box is still one of my favourite unexpected Christmas gifts. Probably a designer thing but I love the playful yet functional design, it made my sad looking lunches so much happier.
alt: A two tiered lunch box thar looks like a salmon sashimi

title: IKEA Frekvens
body: This was one of the first design objects I ever received as a gift from a group of designers. I loved the aesthetics, functionality of the speaker lamps paired with its modular components. This also introduced me to the talented Teenage Engineering (which I’m also now a fan of).
alt: An IKEA square, black speaker that also doubles as a lamp

title: Birkenstock Gizeh
body: As someone who has weird feet but loves flip flops, these were a perfectly casual and stylish alterative that comes with additional support and comfort for my feet. I love how it is now so well worn that it has a mould of my entire feet.
alt: Stone coloured leather Birkenstock sandals

title: Horizn Studio Gion
body: It was a random afternoon when I walked by a minimalist store that I was intrigued by and came out with what I did not realise, would be one of my most used and favourite bum bags. I take it with me on every holiday because of how handy it is. It may be small, but it is the perfect size that can fit in my phone, wallet, keys or passport with a small pack of tissues. Bonus points for it being waterproof and durable.
alt: A black waterproof bum bag from Horizn Studio

title: Totem (2019)
body: Totem - a book that brings back memories from my first in person design conference, OFFF in Barcelona, 2019. That was also where I discovered all the cool folks like ManvsMachine and B-reel.
alt: A black limited edition book from the OFFF festival in Barcelona

title: Keychron K3
body: Designing with ergonomics in mind, it is an ultra slim wireless keyboard with keycaps for Windows and Mac. It has an aluminium body and connects with up to 3 devices. It weighs about 483g and measures 306mm x 116mm.
alt: A wireless mechnical keyboard from Keychron
